Description: Sempra agreed to pay Nevada $30 million over seven years to settle a lawsuit filed in November 2002 alleging conspiracy to manipulate of the energy market.

The California Attorney General, along with the California Air Resources Board, the Los Angeles City Attorney, and the County of Los Angeles announced a $119.5 million settlement with the Southern California Gas Company over the natural gas leak from a ruptured well at its Aliso Canyon Natural Gas Storage Facility in Porter Ranch, California. Discovered on October 23, 2015, the leak caused natural gas to flow into the air for several months, releasing up to 109,000 metric tons of methane into the environment before the well was sealed in February 2016.
disability
Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Description: Southern California Gas Co. pleaded no contest to a charge of failing to immediately report a gas leak at its Aliso Canyon Natural Gas Storage Facility. Along with the plea it agreed to implement new monitoring systems, making the estimated penalties and costs $4 million.

SDG&E agreed to pay $27 million in settlement of alleged liabilities to the City of San Diego for its role in starting the Witch Fire, which caused losses to the city from emergency response costs, loss of lease revenue, damage to structures including the city reservoir, and ecological damage.

Description: FY 2005 and 2006 System Average Interruption Frequency Index violation
Feeders with a System Average Interruption Frequency Index that fell below standard

For reporting year 2008, Oncor reported it had 76 feeders with a System Average Interruption Duration Index (SAIDI) value in the top 10% of the worst feeders for two or more consecutive years, 60 feeders with a System Average Interruption Frequency Index (SAIFI) value in the top 10% of its worst feeders for two or more consecutive years, 21 feeders with a SAIDI value more than 300% greater than system average for two or more consecutive years, and 4 feeders with a SAIFI value more than 300% greater than the system average for two or more consecutive years.

Description: A Settlement Agreement between Sempra, the California Attorney General, and the Commission resolved a complaint that the Sempra companies made certain written and oral representations and other statements before the Commission that allegedly resulted in inadequate resource planning and system capability culminating in periods of curtailment of natural gas service to certain SDG&E non-core customers in 2000 and 2001.  The Settlement provides installment payments to be made over 2 years beginning in October 2009.

The Commission adopted the settlement agreement between CPSD and SDG&E which provides that while SDG&E does not admit to any violation of Rule 1.1 of the Commission's Rules of Practice and Procedure, it acknowledges its failure to fully comply with Rule 8.3 and tenders an apology for imprecision in its communications with decision-makers in connection with certain ex parte meetings held during Phase 2. SDG&E commits to pay a total of $920,000 in shareholder funds in amounts specified for charitable contributions, reimbursement to the Commission for expenses related to this proceeding, and payment to the State's General Fund. Further, SDG&E commits to develop a professional responsibility class and an ex parte best practices manual, both in consultation with the Commission.
Notes: The source provides only the year, so the date is listed here as January 1.

Description: Cox Communications and San Diego Gas and Electric (SDG&E) jointly moved for the approval and adoption of their respective Settlement Agreements, which resolved the Commission's Orders Instituting Investigations 08-11-006 and 08-11-007 regarding the Witch, Rice and Guejito fires. Under the terms of the Agreement, SDG&E will pay $14,350,000 to the General Fund of the State of California. SDG&E will also reimburse CPSD up to an additional $400,000 in order to implement a computer work module to assist CPSD.
San Diego Gas and Electric was cited $5,000 for a resource adequacy deficiency that was cured within five business days from the date of notification.
Notes: The source provides only the year, so the date is listed here as January 1.

Description: Citation issued to Southern California Gas Company
Citation to Southern California Gas Company for failing to take prompt remedial action to correct deficiencies found in its corrosion control of its natural gas pipeline system
CEQA citation issued to Southern California Gas Company for Failure to comply with mitigation measures outlined in the Final Environmental Impact Report included in the projects' Permit to Construct.
Notes: The source provides only the year, so the date is listed here as January 1.

Description: Citation to SoCalGas for failure to properly report to the CPUC and the National Response Center the 11/24/18 gas incident that occurred in Oxnard
PG&E for failure to properly identify utility service lines which resulted in a natural gas incident that occurred on March 10, 2018 in San Jose, Calif.

The California Public Utilities Commission fined Southern California Gas Company (SoCalGas) $8,058,200 million for failing to issue and prorate timely monthly customer bills, resulting in higher than normal bills, and extending the billing period for a significant number of customers.
SoCalGas for three separate violations which resulted in a natural gas incident that occurred on July 15, 2019 in Murrieta, CA
